posts.name: James
posts.cooked:
Hello, so we just assembled our ThriftyBot Elevator Kit, and the elevator is getting caught up on the screw cover on the base stage. Is there any way to fix this/did we do something wrong? Any advice would be greatly appreciated!

IMG_3757 1920×2560 200 KB IMG_3758 1920×2560 286 KB

IMG_3757 1920×2560 200 KB

IMG_3757 1920×2560 200 KB

IMG_3758 1920×2560 286 KB

IMG_3758 1920×2560 286 KB

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I don’t think the bearing block is meant to be able to slide past that spacer. You’re probably meant to put that extrusion that spans across it on after putting the elevator stages on the inside. If you look at the build guide video this is what they do.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Also this could just be something with the angle but this extrusion looks kinda bent, try not to overtighten your screws when you’re assembling. IMG_2758 750×1334 730 KB

IMG_2758 750×1334 730 KB

IMG_2758 750×1334 730 KB

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked: Can you place the cross bar at the top of the mast, that way the roller don’t have to go through the spacers?

Agreeing with what others have already said.

In addition though you can also try purchasing ultra low profile head screws from McMaster Carr.

posts.name: Lucas Santos
posts.cooked: We’re using a TTB elevator kit just like this. We constructed the main frame and the individual stages on their own, then mated them together after assembly. You can do this by temporarily removing all of the 1/2in OD bearings (the ones that stick out from the sides of the elevator blocks and are currently interfering with your top cross bar) and the hardware that attaches them to the bearing blocks, fitting the frames inside of each other, and replacing the bearings.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: A few more pictures may be helpful, but it looks like the bottom of your inside sliding stage is above the crossbar. Typically that doesn’t slide past it but if your design requires that, McMaster does sell low profile and ‘ultra low profile’ 1/4-20 bolts that would give you more clearance for that area - McMaster-Carr
